reviewText:
Everybody look at me 'cause I'm sailin' on a boat!

After two hours of play, I have to say that I'm impressed.  After just a couple tutorial missions (each and all skippable in turn), I was turned loose to make or break my company.  After a few lucrative ore contracts, I found myself smuggling contraband on the Mediterranian.  And got busted.  And my cargo seized.  And fined.  And my ship impounded for a week.  A time-based contract I still had in the hold expired, so there were penalties there.  And harbor masters didn't care to allow convicted smuggers in their ports, so harbor fees went up.  All that in two hours and not a moment that felt repeatative.

A few features that I liked:  Your home port determines what bonuses your company gets.  I picked Lisbon for +5% on ore contracts and -10% to fuel.  The trick is, the smaller the port, the larger the bonuses.  So you have a reason to keep smaller ports and the ships that can service them.

There is some ship customization.  The Feeder I started with had three levels of Hull and Engine upgrades, which increased range and speed respectively.  There was also a license upgrade that would allow me to carrry what appeared to be hazardous waste.  Unfortunately, there does not appear to be options for custom paint or appearance (other than your ship name emblazoned upon the stern and bow).

I remember reading a comment somewhere saying that the music was repeatative and annoying.  To me, it sounded like every port had it's own song.  And each port felt VERY unique.  I'm already developing favorites and least favorites.

The only meh item I encountered dealt with other ship traffic.  Large ships move fast and looked intimidating at first, but it turns out they can stop on a dime and give the player right-of-way.  I would have liked to have seen navigation lights and right-of-way implemented (and fines for failure to obey maritime traffic laws).

Anyway, back to my ship.  I'm saving up for a fleet.  And I'm naming all my vessels after internet porn sites.

OK, this review is primarily for the campaign game as I still am in the progress of completing it.

THE GOOD:
If you remember Ports Of Call, this game has a very familiar feel to it.  So much so that I would consider it the spiritual successor to that fine game.  The ship docking is nearly identical, smaller feeder ships are more difficult to dock than the larger post panamax & larger ships that have side streamer jets that will allow much better maneuverability than the tiny ships.
Many varied ports are available worldwide to sail into and each port has very unique feel to it.  Hamburg & Santos are especially technical and can be quite challenging and fun to sail into at full speed.  They have an option to pay a tug to skip the manual docking for a fee based on your ship size.  The fee can be quite a hit to the profitability of the runs... Which leads me to the Bad...

THE BAD:
Profitability:  I have noticed that the smaller ships, while they carry much less cargo, and in some cases are significantly slower, are FAR more profitable than the larger ships.  Cargoes are 3 to 5 times more profitable per container than the larger ships.  THIS IS A COLOSSAL FLAW IMO, and a huge reason that my fleet of over 200 post panamax ships is starting to bog down my computer.  I refuse to make runs where the cargo value for my huge UCLV ship is equal to a post panamax ship 3 size classes smaller.
I have found that there are ways to crock the game model by leaving feeder ships in the company contract ports to generate hordes of tiny highly profitable contracts meant for feeder ships, but this exploit should not be needed.  The value of the cargo should remain similar through all the ship classes to motivate players to want to get the giant ships (which are a blast to drive) because they are big money as well as big fun.  Instead I am forced to slog through thousands of port tug fees to remain profitable.  Which leads me to the UGLY...

I am not much of a game player, but have always been interested in the shipping business and business simulation. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed playing this game. Some people will enjoy the docking of the vessels in the various harbors. As you gain experience you will be able to get to and from the dock faster. There may be some small issues with the underlying rules. For example, was surprised I could pickup cargo from NY for Havana. Suspect that isn't a realistic route.--more likely such goods travel to an intermediate port first (like Halifax). Also, not totally sure the rules follow the Jones Act. But one can really spend time figuring out how to keep the vessels as loaded as possible, and efficiently moving the most TEUs for the most money. I didn't like it when my ships had less than 50% of the capacity in use at any one time. I found this more challenging then moving the boats around, and therefore I would sometimes just let the game dock the ship to save time even though it negatively affected my reputation.

Again, not a gamer, but surprised how much time  I have spent playing and enjoying this game. If you like simulations, you'll probably find this entertaining, if not informative.

This is the first game I purchased via the Steam recommendations.  I am certainly not disappointed.  So far, I have 10 hours in the game, and I feel addicted.

This is a fairly simple simulator/logistics game.  The game has a tutorial, and I'm playing through it.  However, if you played similar games, such as Cities in Motion or Railroad Tycoon, then you can probably figure this out.  You buy a ship, get a contract, and then deliver the goods.  You have investors, you can take out a loan, and your ship will need fuel and maintenance.  From that standpoint, it is very easy.  As you get more ships, you gain more capacity but lose some capability.  Eventually, you can create company specific contracts that require delivery of a certain good to a certain location; at this point the complexity starts to become apparent.  To keep it interesting, you also have to deal with storms, pirates, and fires at sea.

While the game is fun to play, it still needs some polish.  I've had a few popup notifications remain on the screen.  I can play through them and sometimes get them to disappear, but its a bug.  While there are hazards, like storms and pirates, they purely random rather location specific, thus avoidable.  For example, I had a piracy near the Canaries, and I hit a storm with one vessel while another vessel sailed through the same area at the same time without the storm.  Personally, I find these oddities to be minor imperfections and potential room for growth in the development.  Overall the game is very solid platform and is good enough for this early release.

A larger area for growth is the games focus on cargo container shipping.  I commented about this in relation to US ports on the forums.  I was happy to see the game designer respond within hours of my comments.  While my request won't go fulfilled for now, I'm satisfied knowing that they understand the issue.

I'm definitely getting my money's worth from the game.  I think the game is playable for most ages.  If you are into sims like this, you'll love it.  If you prefer FPS games, then you'll probably hate this game as it is not meant for you.  I recommend this to all the simmers out there.

reviewText:
I missed seeing this game when it came out, or I would have gotten it sooner, It is a simple cargo ship company tycoon game, very much like the classic 1986 Ports Of Call, with lovely 3D graphics and overall a nicer art style. For those interested, Ports Of Call XXL is in development (www.portsofcall.de), and you can get versions of the classic game as well.

http://www.metallicat95.com/?p=388 -- my review page


TransOcean has all the nice elements for a trading game — transport cargo from port to port, trying to make the most money and boost your reputations in order to improve your shipping company. Travel to more ports, play the ship driving minigame to get in and out of the docks for more status (and to save money and see the nice scenery), buy more ships, complete company contracts, and get rich. Or go bankrupt if you fail, but the game is overall fairly easy to play.
This is a single player game, with a sequel with multiplayer and more features coming out in May 2016,

As such, my recommendation is to get this one on sale, unless you can’t wait to get your ship captain fix now. The polish of this game is a good sign for the future of its replacement, and I expect that you won’t get exactly the same sort of challenges and game play features in the sequel.  This original game does, though, contain the background story and missions which set up the campaign mode of its sequel, and may be a little easier to play (in single player).

There are two basic game modes, the campaign — a mission-driven game with an investor who gives you orders and wants to be paid back, with the ultimate goal to become a tycoon and take control of the company — and the free game, where you just run the shipping company however you want. The campaign can be a challenge to win, but also provides a nice tutorial on how to play.

Much of the joy of the game is making smart choices and watching your company and bank balance grow. You will spend most of your time watching your ships sail around the world, and making decisions when they reach ports. Refuel now, or wait for a cheaper location? Select cargos for the best pay, but take into account the chances of getting new valuable jobs at each destination. Repair or upgrade your ship as needed. Some cargos require upgrades in order to legally carry them — take them without and you risk customs inspections and fines. Time spent sitting in port costs money, so that is another hard choice.

Some jobs have time deadlines. They pay better, increase your status if you are one time, but penalize you if you fail. The company contracts you can take give you a mission to deliver a specific kind of cargo from one specific port to another, with a time limit as well. They add another piece of depth, trading guaranteed work with a good payoff at the end (and more status) for a commitment which makes you miss out on valuable high-paying loads to other locations — or taking them, and risk failing the contract.

All the ships in this game are container cargo ships, and can carry multiple cargo loads as long as they fit on the ship. Sometimes you have enough to fill the ship and go to one destination, but often you must it several destinations in order to travel fully loaded. Each port docked at takes time and money.

Early in the game, you will dock manually and play a simple ship driving game to get into or out of the harbor. It isn’t hard to do being slow and patient, but most of us don’t want to wait too long, and so you take chances and risk damaging your ship. Succeeding boosts your status. Being Famous means you’ll get better deals and cargos than a small, Unknown company and captain.

Later in the game, especially once you’ve seen all the ports in 3D, you’ll just pay the tug costs and skip this part of the game, as long as you have the money in the bank.

There are dangers which can affect your ship’s travel — storms at sea, fires, sickness, reefs, pirates, rescue missions — plus the risk of customs delays if your ship isn’t running legally. Taking the risky illegal goods (counterfeit and questionable merchandise) pays very well, but has much higher fines and delays if you are caught. Plus the illegal goods are confiscated, unlike loads where you aren’t compliant with regulations.

Most trips, though, are uneventful for legal, properly maintained ships. You’ll spend your time making good choices each time a ship hits port, and when you cast off to send it to its next destination. The game proceeds in simulated real time (you can accelerate the clock, and will do so often in the early game). With more ships in play, you will have a lot on your mind, as you try to figure out the best way to make money and complete your missions.

The sequel adds competition -- AI and human multiplayer -- and expands a lot on this game.  But the basic elements seem similar enough, with, I hope, enough improvements to make it a really great game to enjoy with friends.

My review is from single player only. I work for a container shipping company, so this game caught my eye a while ago. I expected something like the classic Railroad Tycoon series, but with ships. What I got was something different, but in a bad way. The game itself isn't horrid, but more something that is vastly inefficient. The mini-game of docking the ships manually when they call ports is tedious and just isn't worth it at almost any point in the game. The whole thing is pointless.

The business element is very lacking, and I was disappointed that the one of only ways they could think to make the game challenging was to vary the same starting scenario. The only thing that changes is the insane interest rate the player is required to pay to the angel investor, along with her ability to sign annoying shipping contracts with huge penalties without your consent. Starting capital should be something the player is in conrol of, or at least given some options. I haven't beaten the game yet, but so far the only risk is getting caught without proper liscense to carry goods and varying interest rates. All of the systematic risks associated with shipping, storms, fire, whatever are all completely random and don't even affect other ships on the same rotues. There is no political risk, market risk, exchange rate risk, or purchasing power risk. The game is supposed to be global, but has nothing global about the simulated economy nor is it dynamic in supply/demand.

Last, and probably the biggest deal breaker, I don't enjoy the micro management required in this game. Having to approve every single ship when you call port is annoying, and it seems almost impossible to set up a static voyage using supply and demand or contracts. Every port you have to pick new goods based on what is available and then decide where the ship is to go next, and because goods cant be transferred at ports for a hub and spoke strategy, the only way to play is by having direct routes for every ship. In late game, you have so many shipts they are calling ports every 4 seconds so the gameplay never feels like it is going anywhere. Youre costantly being inturruped by having to agree to pay the docking fee, load more goods, and then choose the next port. The only way to keep ships in specific areas is to basically micromanage contracts, and have them sit in port waiting for a contract that keeps them from having to go from the EU to Asia, or float them completely empty to another port, which is again heavy micromanagement when you consider how many ships you have to track in late game, and not realistic at all.

These business simulators still have things to learn, and it makes you truely appreciate games which are very well done like the Railroad Tycoon seres. They are still amazing. The next installment of Transcean is out this summer, I hope it is a little better.

reviewText:
Simply put its a great game, if you are interested in a game that is all about managing a network of ships, ensuring you can afford the ships, fuel, repairs and any fines you incure all the while needing to keep enough money in the bank to pay your greedy investor then this may be the game for you.

The graphics are exactly what you would expect from a game that is essentialy a map and a bunch of finance screens, simple clean and easy to understand. The docking part of the game is quite fun but when you have 10+ ships can become very tedious to dock every ship. The advantage of actually docking yourself is you save the moring fee's and when it come to the most expensive ship in the game thats a lot of money especialy if you dock the ship and leave the port. So it comes in handy throughout the game and while you dont need to use it ever it can be useful (especialy if your ships is empty and you need to move to a different port and want to save some money), its also quite fun and challenging as some of the docks are very oddly shapped and possitioned. The graphics for the docking are nice clean and I expect will stand the test of time nicely.

Every aspect of the game is fun, if a bit repetative, however with the docking mini game you can vary it up and keep the fun alive. It does become very repetative nearing the end of the game as you are simply trying to buy out your investor and the money you need is huge and can take a little too long to reach, which is the only real downside to this entire game. I wold have liked to have seen a few other elements like competiton with other companies and the such but alas not in this game. If the game starts to feel repetative try taking on a contract that is restrictive or try and get a chain of contracts, there are many ways to keep your interest, you just need to look for them.

The tutorial is very good and is perfectly integrated into the main game so no need to stop and start. You follow the instructions and you start making money. My personal recomendayion is to always but the ship with the highest top speed and bigest hold, the distance it can travel is imaterial, especialy when you reach level 3 and 4 ships.

Pro's
Graphics are simple and clean and will not feel dated in the years to come
A number of different challenges throughout the game.
Piloting the ships are fun and challenging, the latter ships with thrusters, makes piloting a dream.
Finding the best routes to make money is a lot of fun.


Con's
Can be repetative, especialy later on.
You will hate how much the investor takes from you and can be annoying when you simply want to finish the game.
Becomes a little to easy in the late game.
When you have 15 + ships it still takes forever to buy out the investor

Conclusion, this is a fun game that will keep you occupied for many hours, however its not for everyone and you need to be a tycoon fan to get the most out of this game, and even then trying to end the game will annoy you.

reviewText:
Among the German-style simulation game genre, this one is a gem with tons of polish. There are still minor bugs, but I haven't run into anything game-breaking or that couldn't be resolved without a quick restart.

The docking/undocking minigame is a fun diversion that lets you see the beautiful port cities. As some have mentioned the camera angle is somewhat limited denying you a full panorama, but it's not too terrible. You can zoom out further once you unlock bigger ships, but the camera is locked between about 45 degrees and straight top-down.

The rest of the game is pretty well balanced. There are some random events that provide enough risk/reward to gamble on transporting illegal goods for example, or good you don't own a license for. Sometimes you can get away with it and sometimes customs will seize your haul and hit you with a big fine.

It still remains profitable to keep your starter ships as well. Your $/ton scales depending on the size ship you have. Smaller ships have the highest $/ton while the largest have the smallest, making up for it in sheer bulk.

The campaign puts a progression track in while putting a wrench in the gears every so often to keep things interesting. You will get contracts you were forced to agree to from time to time that have a tight deadline and require a great deal of coordination to pull off.

reviewText:
Recommended overall if on sale, with some caveats.

I liked this game a great deal overall, despite the criticism I'm about to give it. It's been good value and good fun for me. Read on to see if it's for you.

This is a Tycoon game, not at all an accurate ship simulator. It's really more logistics oriented, and the financial aspects are weak. The simplistic mini-game of docking ships helps break the tedium, especially early on, but itself becomes tedious, particularly due to the lengthy loading times. I had no difficulties with the mini-game and I am decidedly not a twitch fast reflexes gamer. That said, casual or older gamers might not like the ship docking mini-game; fortunately it can mostly be skipped at the cost of some revenue. As the game progresses you'll likely be skipping it more and more.

I'd like to say it accurately depicts running a shipping company, but it really doesn't. The financial side of the game is incredibly weak and simplistic, with poor tools (no concept of a balance sheet or even a proper income statement, and some very strange criteria for a successful quarter. (e.g. there's an effort to calculate return on investment, but little concept of the passage of time, so back-loaded heavy ship purchases make your quarter 'unsuccessful' and you lose reputation.)

That said, the logistics (while simplistic compared to a genuine shipping company) are a nice thing, and piecing together company contracts and profitable semi-sustainable routes can be enjoyable for those who like that kind of thing.

Random events can be pretty irritating with wildly disproportionate penalties. More frequent cargo inspections with lower penalties would make more sense from a gaming perspective; as it is, the user is just tempted to reload when a potentially company-destroying penalty is applied randomly every couple of hours.

A couple of major downsides: some have reported major bugs, particularly in late game. While I've not yet encountered game-destroying bugs, I have encountered extreme slowdowns in the interface later in the game, especially with several ships in port. These lead me to suspect the coding to handle shipping consignments is at best weak and poorly optimized.

The final negative point is this, and why I cannot recommend paying full price. It's a quite good game for the first little bit, but the endgame feels very rough and unfinished. The tools to manage a large group of ships (50+) are quite poor, and the developers have indicated they are focusing all efforts on a version 2. At this point the game is more-or-less abandoned. This doesn't mean it's not worth buying; it does mean I don't believe its worth paying full price even if you love tycoon/financial/business games.

TL;DR: Good if on sale and you like tycoon/financial games. Seems rough and unfinished late in the game. Very enjoyable for what it is.

reviewText:
First impressions.
Okay I had over €9M when I arrived in Rotterdam. I’m greedy so I decided that I’ll transport some contraband to Hamburg. The contract was €1.2M! So I loaded up and bravely set off for Hamburg … only to get stopped by the customs for an inspection of my cargo. Who said crime pays? It does not! I got a hefty fine of €2.3M, the cargo was confiscated and my ship was docked for 5 day – so docking fees are added to my punishment. It’s a pity I could not arm my ship with torpedoes.
I have never played this type of game before and I must say I thoroughly enjoy it. The tutorial is adequate and the gameplay is not over complicated. You get to dock your ship in the harbours and can set best times. This is also applicable when casting off. As you progress new ships become available to purchase. Fuel must be purchased wisely because in some ports it is more expensive than in others. Your ship must be maintained in a seaworthy condition and you have decisions to risk and sail through storms or sail safely around it and hope your cargo can be delivered in time and hold thumbs that you have enough fuel to reach port. I would have liked to manage hiring and firing the crew but unfortunately that is not available. The graphics is not overly impressive but the game play very smooth and I did not notice any bugs either.
So, buy this game, buy a ship and don’t transport contraband. Crime does not pay! I give this game a thumbs up.

reviewText:
The business aspect of the game are superficial at best - There's no competition, no global fluctuations in the market, and all you can do is carry project cargo with container ships. Seriously, you can't establish liners services or anything; you're picking up one or two cargoes at best and essentially tramping. It's really not very complex, and the campaign is just a grind. The price of tug service doesn't make sense (It's about 50 to 1000 more than they cost in real life, seriously), and neither do the ship improvements - I have to stop a ship for two days to get a license to carry dangerous goods? Not only is firefighting gear an option, it's only available on the largest ships?

If you're looking for a remotely realistic simulation of the shipping business, give it a pass.

The ship simulation aspect is similarly basic... No transverse thrust on the propeller, only the larger ships have bow and stern thrusters, there's no wind or current and the ships don't have inertia. Seriously, the best way to make a dock perpendicular to the direction you started with is to speed up, then turn at the last minute and slide sideways into it, Dukes of Hazard style.

Give it a pass, and be very careful when considering the new version.

After 2 hours of game play:

I've discovered that manual docking/undock is just ♥♥♥♥! your basically just up against a clock, the fact you cut up 2 other ships to do it doesn't matter! but don't worry you can just use auto-docking!
Also it appears you can't lose money unless your really incompetent! and there's no automation when it comes to management of the ships:
- No auto re-fuel at each stop (an option to auto re-fuel when price in port is below a set amount would be nice)
- You have to choose EVERY SINGLE load, I'm already dreading what that will be like with more than a few ships, surely when you accept a long-term contract you should be able to assign ships to it and leave them go? ultimately I would want to take on multiple long-term contracts and assign some ships to them in a loop so the ships always have loads on them.
- It asks you how you want to dock EVERY TIME ANY SHIP ARRIVES AT A PORT!!! seriously? I'm tempted to say they should do away with the manual docking completely and spent the time saved expanding the rest of the 'game'

After 4 hours:

I can confirm there is absolutely no need to manually dock/undock, there is no gain by doing so, on the starter ships it will cost you 100,000 to auto-dock, which is affordable on all but a couple of jobs.

I've discovered that you can lose money, reefs will randomly appear where there wasn't one before (because that happens!!!), they appear to be the only way so far that I can lose money... except of course the investor taking her money at seemly random times.

So anyway, I got bored after the first 2 hours, but stuck at it and I can tell you that the game doesn't change, all that happens is you get bigger ships, and bigger distances to move things! I've just brought my second panamax ship, I've not even left the starting area (Europe & med) and I'm bored ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I consider the game complete because I feel like I already know exactly what I'm going to be doing for the next few hours till I can buy out the investor which I assume is the end game.

Summary:

I have been looking forward to this game for ages, but I'm glad I listened to reviews and held off till it was on offer because it is a £5 game, The developers are working on a Transocean 2, which I have high hopes for, time will tell!

reviewText:
I like Tycoon games a lot, they're my single favourite genre, so when I saw a game allowing me to be a shipping magnate I was pretty interested. Reviews were mixed but it was on sale for only a few pounds so I took a gamble.

To keep this short, the game is relatively fun but quickly becomes repetitive and my patience has worn thin long before completing a single play through of the campaign mode. You start the game, buy a ship at your home port and select one of the available contracts to ship goods across the globe. You watch a little graphic of your ship go from port to port and when you dock at the other end you earn your money (or not as the case may be), sound fun? Well I hope so because you're going to do that thousands and thousands of times. You buy more ships and bigger ships and upgrade ships to carry different cargo but it all boils down to selecting contracts, sending your ship to sea and watching the moeny roll in.

I've sunk enough hours in to this that I've got my moneys worth (less than a pound per hours gameplay at time of writing) and whilst I certainly don't feel ripped off I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone but the most die hard management/tycoon fan.

Overall not bad but not interesting either.

reviewText:
TransOcean is a game that is out for a very select type of people. It is not going to be fun for everyone because the gameplay is very limited. Control of the ships themselves is actually considered to be a minigame and for a small price can be bypassed. At first bypassing is too expensive, but your larger ships can afford the cost.  After the minigame all there is to do is to take out loans, and manage contracts for a fleet of ships that you can somewhat custimize. I also experienced a bug which prevents me from naming new ships.

Even after all of my problems the game was beautiful. After a hard day of trucking I relaxed to a easy game that was one of the most beautiful looking games that is not from a AAA company. I wished there were more features, more ship types, more ports from the world, more of everything. But for now I can play this game, but this game will not be for those who are looking for a challenge or a shipping update from older games close to this genre. TransOcean is what it is, a simple beautiful game with limited options. I love how it relaxes me, you may not like it.

Also the online portion of it is just you in sandbox mode and prices go up and down online. It actually makes it easier has some prices skyrocket up.

reviewText:
TransOcean is a pretty cool and fun game where you just run your own maritime shipping company and you can run as many ships that you can afford. The ships range from a tiny freighter to a Panamax to a UCLV (a really big ship) and you can ship goods from ore to counterfeit goods to weapons to and from countries in the world.

Gameplay wise, it's pretty simple and there is a mini game where you can dock and cast off. It does get repetitive after a while but if you play the game in bursts, it's fun. There are challenges where you can accept company contracts to ship a certain number of goods from one port to another in a certain time frame, which is rewarding in the end. There are also random events that pop up where you decide to avoid it or go through it, as well as customs checks from time to time (often on Hard difficulty). One neat feature I love about the game is there is online connectivity where players who play this game effect prices of goods if a port is visited often.

However, what I do find is that when you start expanding, the amount of ships that you have to manage gets overwhelming and I wish there was a way to easily load your freighters at multiple ports.

Overall, I do recommend this game but remember to play it in bursts or it will get repeititive. Score wise, about a 8/10.

reviewText:
When I first read about TransOcean Shipping, I added it to my wishlist and followed it closely for several months. The mixed reviews made me skeptical about buying it, but as I'd been starved for a good business simulation, decided to take the gamble - and I'm pleased I did!

In the game you play the founder of a shipping company, whom takes on an investor to fund his company. Starting off with one small 'Feeder' ship, you have to accept contracts and weigh decisions over speed/fuel consumption to ensure that deliveries are made on time. The campaign aspect of the game provides extra challenge, allowing you to unlock larger vessels as you progress in rank and prestige, whilst constantly trying to ensure you have enough money to provide the investor her regular payments.

Ships can be docked and cast off manually, which offers you the chance to control your ship if you'd rather avoid paying the tug fees (automatic docking/cast off) in ports. This can provide a nice little break from the 'main map' game screen, which is where you'll spend most of your time. Eventually you'll have a fleet of different sized ships, and will need to juggle factors of tight deadlines, contract penalties and the various ship sizes permitted to dock in certain ports etc.

Despite the fact that you spend so much time staring at the map screen, the challenge and reward of juggling everything around is thoroughly entertaining. It's a game that doesn't require too much thought and that you can play casually. I personally found the game addictive, but I appreciate that it won't appeal to everyone - I'm sure many would find the lack of variation a little tiresome/boring. If you're unsure whether you'd enjoy this game, do what I did and check a gameplay video online. There are many to watch, and will give you an accurate idea of how this game plays.

reviewText:
**Contains game details to make points, so beware spoilers.**

Game was interesting and had a lot of good bits, but was too shallow overall. There's no real company progress, just meet a few requirements and you unlock the next bigger ship; rinse and repeat. They did a job creating an investor that you'll grow a seething hatred for as she continues to leech your funds ever quarter whilst creating contracts that you can't complete without breaking the law [get product X from city Y; this city only allows the tiniest ships to dock at it, and you need an upgrade to lawfully carry product X - an upgrade that the tiniest ship cannot get]. The end game requires building up a very large amount of spare cash to free yourself from the investor; the amount is 2x the company's late-game value, so if you're punished if you like to have some spare cash on hand. Building a large fleet - which is required to buy out the company - generates a ton of busywork, as there's no sort of automation available. I really enjoy sim-management games, but this one punishes you unless you grind towards great profits; mainly, trying to keep your head above water as Ms. BS gouges you for 10% of your value every quarter [her name is Ms. Blythe-Smith, but maybe the initials were chosen intentionally]. I think I would have enjoyed TransOcean much more if it focused on managing the company rather than managing the minutia.

The ability to manually dock and cast off is fun, but it gets tedious considering how many shipping runs you must make; I think if you did every maneuver manually it'd about triple the amount of time played, and eventually feels a bit like busy work [the game forces you to do some maneuvers later game in order to progress, which may help some discover this bit they've been missing out on, but it also feels forced for those that want to focus on the management aspect].

It looks like a TO2 is in progress, and I'll probably check it out based on how it looks and the price. TO isn't a bad game, and I was on the fence about giving a 'No' recommendation. I'd probably give it a 7/10 overall - there are just many better games in genre to spend time on, especially ones that have better replay value.

reviewText:
**Contains game details to make points, so beware spoilers.**

Game was interesting and had a lot of good bits, but was too shallow overall. There's no real company progress, just meet a few requirements and you unlock the next bigger ship; rinse and repeat. They did a job creating an investor that you'll grow a seething hatred for as she continues to leech your funds ever quarter whilst creating contracts that you can't complete without breaking the law [get product X from city Y; this city only allows the tiniest ships to dock at it, and you need an upgrade to lawfully carry product X - an upgrade that the tiniest ship cannot get]. The end game requires building up a very large amount of spare cash to free yourself from the investor; the amount is 2x the company's late-game value, so if you're punished if you like to have some spare cash on hand. Building a large fleet - which is required to buy out the company - generates a ton of busywork, as there's no sort of automation available. I really enjoy sim-management games, but this one punishes you unless you grind towards great profits; mainly, trying to keep your head above water as Ms. BS gouges you for 10% of your value every quarter [her name is Ms. Blythe-Smith, but maybe the initials were chosen intentionally]. I think I would have enjoyed TransOcean much more if it focused on managing the company rather than managing the minutia.

The ability to manually dock and cast off is fun, but it gets tedious considering how many shipping runs you must make; I think if you did every maneuver manually it'd about triple the amount of time played, and eventually feels a bit like busy work [the game forces you to do some maneuvers later game in order to progress, which may help some discover this bit they've been missing out on, but it also feels forced for those that want to focus on the management aspect].

It looks like a TO2 is in progress, and I'll probably check it out based on how it looks and the price. TO isn't a bad game, and I was on the fence about giving a 'No' recommendation. I'd probably give it a 7/10 overall - there are just many better games in genre to spend time on, especially ones that have better replay value.

reviewText:
This game is a lot like any management game, like space empire building without the conflict of war. In this case your focus is on fleet building and freight management. They have put in a lot of antagonist elements that take the place of conflict-based issues of other games, like an investor that you have to buy out eventually, otherwise the ♥♥♥♥♥ keeps saddling you with difficult contracts (missions) that set you back. Also, her quarterly dividend is 10% of your company's holdings: So when I as at nearly a billion $ in the bank and many ships in my fleet, she came along and was taking nearly $200 million every quarter.

The game is primarily a management game at the strategic map level. There is a 3D mini-game where you can pilot your ships in and out of the ~60 ports, each rendered on actual ports. You don’t have to do the mini game, but it costs you harbour pilot fees to dock and undock, so I usualy pilot the big ships myself and let the harbour pilot do the smaller ones, because the fees for the big shps are crazy!

They could do so much more with this game though: The only online element is that the price of commodities you ship is driven by what all the other players are doing in their games (if you want true online multiplayer you need to buy TOSC: Rivals), otherwise it is a private single player experience; They could have also had a design and build your own ship element (currently you can only buy new or used predefined ship classes); They also could have had far more ports with greater variation in freight and range of commodities; I would have also like to see a 3D first person on the bridge feature to reallt challenge you in the mini-game.

I have to admit that I am enjoying the management side of it as well as the gamification aspect of the quests/challenges/missions. However, I can see how after a while it will seem pointless and get boring. Maybe it would be different on a more diffilcut level, but the introductory 'easy' level is too easy, but that’s where the excelent tutorial and assistance feature sits, so that what I started with.

I also have to admit that I am using Excel to help track things: I have a 4-sheet .xlsx that tracks the ports, freight, ships, routes, contracts, challenges, etc., becasue the in-game lists and tracking are not as effective at getting at ithout closing existing screens. It could have done the interface a lot better.
